div.head:
Embleme 35. Of the Secrets of Nature.
As Ceres accustomed Triptolemus, and Thetis Achilles to abide in
fire, soe allso doth an artist the stone.

lg.l: By documents, the hottest flames endur'dendured:
Thetis and Ceres thus did them sustaine,
By night with fire, ith'in the day with milke amaind.
As to a babe the breast is naturall,
Soe fire to th' med'cine Philosophicall.

div.head: Discourse 35.
div.ab:
Lycurgus that Law=maker of the Spartans Shewed to the people in-
an assembly in the Theater by an ocular example, how farre custome
and use whether good or evill may prævayle, hee bringing in two whelps
produced at one litter, and between both setting a pott full of meat,-
and a hare, one of which whelps seeing the food and the hare, left
the food and pursud the hare, because hee was soe accustomed, but
the other not regarding the hare, emptyed the pott, hee being allso-
soe accustomed: which being done, behold, sayth hee, here you see by
little ones, how farre education and custome may prævayle, even in those,
which nature hath produced exactly alike, and of the same litter: After
this manner therefore is it convenient to rectify or direct nature to bet
ter things, which is as wax, easily flexible to vice or virtue. That-
which hee hath demonstrated to be true in politicks, the Philosophers
doe agree to be allso soe in Physicks. How effectuall custome is in-
men and brutes daily examples are seen throughout the whole world,
in vegetables allso are many obvious, but in minerall and metallicke-
bodyes wee have not soe much experience: yet neverthelesse they fix
their stone by custome in fire agreable to it, as they in innumerable-
places doe signify: For it must be nourished by fire, as a child by milke
upon its mothers breasts: whereupon sayth Emiganus; behold the babe-
sucking, and hinder him not: And Bodillus, The infant borne is nou
rished by milke and fire alone, and by little and little whilst hee
is very young, and the more hee is burned, his bones being comforted,
hee is brought to youth, to which attaining, hee is able to provide for-
himselfe: And Arnold in the Rosary booke 2. Chapt 7. Yet the Medicine
must be a long time roasted by fire, and nourished as a child-
with the breasts. These same things have the most ancient Philo
sophers been pleased to demonstrate by the allegoryes of Triptole
mus and Achilles accustomed to lye and being hardened in fire, they
both denoting nothing els but the Chymicall subject, besides which
the fable would be insignificant and absurd, unworthy either to be
appropriated to other morall things, or inculcated to the ears of the-
learned: Ceres did as a Nurce feed Triptolemus in the day time-
with milke, and in the night layd him in fire, whereupon the-
youth being very well nourished, his father Eleusius at length-
tooke notice of it: hereupon Ceres killd Eleusius, and gave the-
youth Triptolemus a chariott drawne with winged Dragons,-
whereby hee passd through the aire into all parts of the world,-
and taught men how to sow corne: But this Triptolemus is the-
tincture nourished by fire after a Philosophicall manner, which
being drawne by Serpents, that is, Mercury, taught men how the
Discourse 3.
Philosophers seeds are to be cast into their earth. These same things
are ascribed to Osiris, who to tha end tooke a view of the whole world,
as wee have elswhere demonstrated, and to Dionysius, who travelled-
throughout the world teaching men the use of wine: Now these three
Triptolemus, Osiris, and Dionysius are of one intention and office,-
yea one thing; as allso Achilles, who being most valiant was to be-
sent to the Trojane warre; his father was Peleus, that is, earth, or the
mountaine Peleus, his mother Thetis goddesse of the Sea or waters; from
these Achilles descended: But at their nuptialls the golden apple of Eris
was produced, the first cause of the Trojane warre, wherefore pro
ceding from those nuptialls reason there was that hee should determine
it: Achilles is sayd to be hardened by his mother after the same manner-
as the aforesayd Triptolemus by Ceres, concerning whome wee have
sayd enough in the 6th booke of Hieroglyphicks, which here to repeat-
wee thinke superfluous. The nutriment therefore of the Stone is fire,
but it is not thereby (as some may falsely imagine) extended into lon
gitude, latitude, and profundity, nor doth it receive increment in-
weight; because it acquires onely virtue, maturation, and colour from
fire, carrying all the rest with it as viaticke provisions: For when its-
parts are from severall places congested, purged, and conjoyned, it hath in
it all things requisite for it: Whereupon sayth a Philosopher in the Ro
sary. Omnia fert Secum quibus indiget hæc aqua fætum.
Nor indeed is any strange thing added to it from the beginning to the
end, except it be homogeneous, nor separated, if not heterogeneous:-
But every man ought to consider, before hee begin any thing, how hee
may come to the knowledge of those Dragons that are to be joyned to
the chariot of Triptolemus, which are winged and volatile, which
if you desire to know, you will find them in the Philosophicall dung:-
for they are dung, and are generated from dung, and are that vessell,
which Mary sayth, is not negromanticall, but the regiment of your
fire, without which you will effect nothing: I have revealed to you-
the truth, which by incredible pains I acquired from the monuments
of the Ancients, not without the expense of many years. . . .
